keyTakeAways: Bolivians elected Rodrigo Paz of the Christian Democratic Party (PDC) as president in a run-off vote, ending 20 years of MAS governance.
Paz won 54.5% of the vote with 97% of ballots counted, defeating Jorge Quiroga, who received 45.4%.
Paz, 58, is the son of former President Jaime Zamora and has held positions including city councillor, mayor of Tarija, and senator.
Paz’s campaign promises include tax cuts, tariff reductions, and decentralisation of government under a 'capitalism for all' model.
The MAS party lost power after internal divisions, Morales’s disqualification due to term limits, and economic crisis.
The country faces high inflation (nearly 25%), fuel and food shortages, and public protests over rising prices.
Paz’s policies are ambiguous on fuel subsidies, with claims to restrict them to vulnerable groups.
Opposition from Evo Morales remains strong, especially among Indigenous communities, despite his disqualification from running.
The election reflects a shift in political power from the left-wing MAS to a centre-right alternative in Bolivia.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a pivotal political shift, Bolivia has elected Rodrigo Paz of the centre-right Christian Democratic Party (PDC) as president, ending nearly two decades of governance by the Movement for Socialism (MAS) party. With 54.5% of the vote in the run-off election, Paz narrowly outpaced right-wing candidate Jorge Quiroga, who received 45.4%. The election follows a major defeat for MAS in August’s preliminary vote, triggered by Evo Morales’s disqualification due to term limits and the split within the left-wing coalition. Bolivia faces severe economic challenges, including nearly 25% inflation, fuel and food shortages, and declining energy revenues since Morales’s tenure ended. Paz, son of former president Jaime Zamora, has pledged a 'capitalism for all' agenda with tax cuts, tariff reductions, and decentralisation, though his position on fuel subsidies remains unclear. Despite the shift in power, opposition from Morales—especially among Indigenous communities—remains strong, underscoring the political volatility and deep social divisions in the country.
title: Bolivia elects centre-right Rodrigo Paz as president
